China c Polymer Laboratory, National Centre of Excellence in Physical Chemistry University of Peshawar, 25120, Pakistan Polymer Laboratory, National Centre of Excellence in Physical Chemistry University of Peshawar 25120 Pakistan Polymer Laboratory, National Centre of Excellence in Physical Chemistry University of Peshawar, 25120, Pakistan ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Physics, College of Sciences & Institute for Sustainable Energy, Shanghai University, 200444, PR China. Department of Physics, College of Sciences & Institute for Sustainable Energy, Shanghai University 200444 PR China To improve efficiency of hydrogen production, other anodic reactions with lower theoretical potential like urea oxidation reaction (UOR) to replace OER were explored. Herein, we synthesized FeCo layered double hydroxide (FeCo-LDH) in situ on nickel foam (NF) that had excellent OER and UOR catalytic ability and durability. The good catalytic performance can be attributed to the special crossed nanosheet structured FeCo-LDH with large specific surface area, rapid electron transfer. At the current density of 50 mA cm−2, the overpotential is 228 mV during OER, and the voltage value is 1.353 V vs. RHE during UOR. When FeCo-LDH was used as electrocatalyst, the voltages required for water and urea electrolysis to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 are 1.523 V and 1.409 V, respectively. The strategy of constructing FeCo-LDH on NF plays an important role in high efficiency hydrogen production, and has great application prospects in sustainable energy efficient conversion. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords FeCo-LDH Oxygen evolution reaction Urea oxidation reaction Water splitting 1 Introduction As a clean energy, hydrogen energy has great application potential in many areas due to the high efficiency and low pollution. At present, there are many ways to obtain H2, in which water splitting is one of the most economical and environmentally friendly ways [1–3] . However, the reaction rate of the cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) of water electrolysis is subject to the corresponding anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [4–6] . Because the kinetics of the 4-electron transfer process of OER is slow and requires a higher overpotential, the efficiency of the overall water electrolysis process is low and the energy consumption is increased [7]. In order to alleviate this problem, the development of high-performance and low-cost OER catalysts or the replacement of OER with other anodic reactions that are easier to happen are of great significance for reducing the electrical potential and overall energy consumption required in the H2 production process. At present, the anodic electrooxidation reactions of methanol, ethanol, glucose and other substances have been researched to replace OER reaction in water electrolysis [8–11]. Among them, urea as an important and cheap industrial chemical, is one of the most simple organic compound fertilizers [12] . However, urea will spontaneously degrade to ammonia and nitrate, which will cause serious environmental problems and health problems when discharged into the atmosphere and groundwater. When the urea oxidation reaction (UOR) is used as an anode to assist water splitting to produce H2, its theoretical voltage (0.37 V vs. RHE) is much lower than the traditional water electrolysis voltage (1.23 V vs. RHE), which can produce H2 with lower energy consumption, and provides a prospect for the purification of urea-rich wastewater [13–15]. Noting that, UOR is a process involving 6-electron transfer, and its product is a mixed gas of N2 and CO2. Although the theoretical potential is low, its slow rate due to the complex reaction process, which also causes the problem of excessive overpotential [16,17]. Therefore, researchers need to continue to explore better performance UOR catalysts. So far, like electrocatalysts in OER, the noble metal-based catalysts such as IrO2 and RuO2 have been reported having great catalytic performance for UOR [18,19]. However, high price and low reserves limit their large-scale application in OER and UOR [20–22]. So, more and more non-noble metal-based catalysts, such as transition metal oxides, hydroxides, phosphides, sulfide, etc. were researched for catalysting OER and UOR [23–30]. Based on the above discussion, we prepared self-supported FeCo-LDH on nickel foam (NF) with low cost and excellent performance through simple hydrothermal reaction. FeCo-LDH is grown in situ on the NF substrate, which can be used as electrode directly, and binder is not necessary. Therefore, a close combination between the catalyst and the substrate greatly increase the charge transfer rate [31,32]. Moreover, FeCo-LDH/NF has a crossed nanosheet structure with good structural stability, and the morphology before and after the catalytic reaction remains basically unchanged. As a result, at a current density of 50 mA cm−2, the overpotential is only 228 mV during OER, and the voltage value is only 1.353 V vs. RHE during UOR. At a current density of 10 mA cm−2, the potentials of electrolysis of water and urea are 1.523 V and 1.409 V vs. RHE, respectively. FeCo-LDH is grown in situ on NF to obtain a self-supporting electrode, which is a simple method to prepare low-cost, high-performance electrocatalysts. This strategy has great application potential in the electrolysis of water and urea to produce H2. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and reagents The chemical reagents used were analytical reagent grade, without any treatment before use. Ferric Nitrate Nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3.9 H2O), Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2.6 H2O), Ammonium fluoride (NH4F), urea, hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36–38%) ethanol (EtOH, ≥99.9%), Nafion® (5 wt%) and Pt/C (20 wt%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical. Ru2O (Ru > 75%) was purchased from Suzhou Sinero Technology Co. Ltd. 2.2 Experimental section The NF itself can also play a weak catalytic role as a substrate for in-situ growth, which needs to be pretreated prior to use to remove surface impurities and oxide layers. The treatment method is as follows: The cut NFs are soaked in 3 M HCl solution for 15 min, then ultrasonic washed with deionized water (DI water) and ethanol for three times, and dried at room temperature. 1 mmol Fe(NO3)3.9 H2O, 2 mmol Co(NO3)2.6 H2O, 6 mmol NH4F, 10 mmol urea are distributed in 30 mL DI water, and stirred magnetically until the raw material dispersed evenly, transfer to the 50 mL Teflon reactor lining, then add cleaned NF, heated to 120 °C for 12 h. The sample was ultrasonically washed several times with DI water and ethanol to remove samples that did not grow on the surface of NF, and then oven-dried overnight at 60 °C to obtain the FeCo-LDH. For comparison, we also prepared catalysts without Co or Fe as control experiments, labeled Fe-LDH and Co-LDH, respectively. The synthesis method is the same as FeCo-LDH, but without Co or Fe source. 2.3 Material characterization For research the composition and crystal phase structure, chemical state, morphology and structure of FeCo-LDH/NF, the X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/MAX2500V+/PC with Cu Kα used as the irradiation source，λ = 1.54056 Å), scanning electron microscope (SEM, Phenom Pharos), transmission electron microscope and high resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM and HR-TEM, JEOL JEM-2100 F with Cs-corrected, Japan), X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, USA) were applied. 2.4 Electrochemical characterization The electrochemical data were measured on the CHI760e electrochemical workstation. A three-electrode system was used in the OER and UOR tests, and electrocatalysts grown in situ or driped on NF with a size of 1 × 1 cm2, Hg/HgO electrode, and graphite rod were used as the working, reference, and counter electrode, Preparation of ink for powdered samples (e.g., RuO2, Pt/C, and powdered FeCo-LDH): 5 mg electrocatalyst was dispersed in a mixed solution of 0.495 mL EtOH, 0.495 mL DI water, and 0.01 mL Nafion®, and then ultrasonically treat it resulted in ink. The powdered samples were made by adding 100 µL of prepared ink onto NF (1 ×1 cm2) drop by drop, and then air-drying. According to the equation: E RHE = E Hg / HgO + 0.059 × pH + 0.098 , the potentials in tests were transformed to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The scan rate of linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) was 5 mV s−1. A two-electrode system was used for the electrolysis of water and urea, and both positive and negative electrodes were FeCo-LDH on NF. The scan rate of LSV was 2 mV s−1. Among them, the electrolytes were 1 M KOH with or without 0.5 M urea. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was tested under open circuit potential in the frequency range of 0.01–100,000 Hz. For checking on the observed currents rooted in O2 evolution, the Faraday efficiency (FE) has been researched. The rotary ring-disk electrode (RRDE, the diameter of the disk is 4 mm, and the outer diameter of the ring is 6 mm.) test was performed in 1 M N2 - saturated KOH solution at 1600 rpm with ring voltage of 0.4 V vs. RHE. The O2 was produced at the disk electrode and consumed at the ring electrode. The value of FE can be calculated using the following equation [33] : (1) FE = 2 i r N c i d Where i r and i d are the ring and disk current density, respectively, and N c is the collection efficiency (0.37). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Physical characterization The construction process of FeCo-LDH/NF was shown in Fig. 1a. The urea and NH4F acted as precipitant and growth director respectively to induce the morphological growth of FeCo-LDH. After reacting at 120 °C for 12 h in the autoclave, FeCo-LDH has a loading capacity of ~3 mg cm−2 on NF. As SEM image (Fig. 1b) showed, the thickness of the FeCo-LDH nanosheets is about 50–100 nm. These nanosheets are evenly staggered on the NF, thereby increasing the specific surface area, which is beneficial to electron transfer and mass transfer. The TEM image (Fig. S1a) reveals the microstructure of FeCo-LDH with thin layer. The HR-TEM image (Fig. S1b) shows lattice fringes of FeCo-LDH with spacings of ~0.264 nm and ~0.270 nm, corresponding to the (012) and (101) planes, respectively. The EDS mappings of FeCo-LDH on NF (Fig. S2) confirm that Fe, Co, O, and Ni elements are evenly distributed in the detected area. Accordingly, SEM images of Fe-LDH and Co-LDH also show their distinctive morphologies (Fig. S3)，among them, Fe-LDH has a heterogeneous nanosheet structure as a whole, but there are globular morphology with a diameter of more than 500 nm embedded in it, which cannot be washed away by ultrasonic washing, indicating that it is directly grown on NF (Fig. S3a), and Co-LDH has a nanoacicular structure with dense distribution, but partial aggregation will reduce the specific surface area (Fig. S3b). To further explore the composition and phase purity of FeCo-LDH on NF, X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern is performed (as shown in Fig. 1c). The strong peaks at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.9°, and 76.4° in the XRD pattern correspond exactly to Ni metal (PDF card no. 04–0850). The pattern is well consistent with the standard card of FeCo-LDH (PDF card no. 50–0235), the peaks locating at 2θ = 11.6°, 23.4°, 34.1°, 38.8°, 46.2°, 59.1° and 60.5° are corresponding to crystal planes (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113), respectively. This indicates that FeCo-LDH has good crystallinity. As a control, the XRD patterns of Fe-LDH and Co-LDH are also shown in Fig. S4. To further investigate the elements and chemical state of FeCo-LDH on NF, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed ( Fig. 2). The corresponding XPS survey spectrum shows in Fig. S5 with peaks of C 1 s, O 1 s, Fe 2p, Co 2p, and Ni 2p, which illustrates the elemental composition of FeCo-LDH on NF. In the Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 2a), the complex and asymmetric peaks illustrate the co-existence of Fe2+ and Fe3+ [34] . The peaks at ~711.5 eV and ~724.7 eV corresponding to Fe2+ and the peaks at ~714.5 eV and ~727.2 eV corresponding to Fe3+ are belong to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively. In addition, the satellite peaks of Fe are located at ~719.7 and ~733.7 eV. Fig. 2b shows the spectra of Co 2p, and six fitted peaks at ~780.6 eV, ~782.4 eV, ~796.7 eV, ~798.0 eV, ~786.4 eV, and ~803.0 eV arising from the Co 2p3/2 (Co3+ and Co2+), Co 2p1/2 (Co3+ and Co2+), and two satellite peaks, respectively. As for O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 2 c), the peaks of O1 to O3 at the binding energy of ~529.3 eV, ~531.5 eV, and ~533.2 eV are related to the presence of matal-O, hydroxyl and carboxyl group, respectively [34–36]. As illustrated in Fig. 2d, the high-resolution Ni 2p XPS spectrum exhibits four peaks, Ni 2p3/2 peak (~856.1 eV), Ni 2p1/2 peak (~873.8 eV), and their two satellite peaks which are at the binding energy of ~862.0 eV and ~880.0 eV, respectively, which are spectra of Ni metal derived from NF [37] . 3.2 Electrochemical characterization The electrocatalytic OER activity of FeCo-LDH, Fe-LDH, Co-LDH, and bare NF is evaluated by three-electrode system in 1 M KOH. The iR-corrected OER linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of FeCo-LDH and other catalysts are shown and compared in Figs. 3a and S6. The significant oxidation peaks appear around 1.36 V vs. RHE at these curves, which are caused by the oxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+ [38] . Compared with other catalysts, FeCo-LDH has lowest onset potential under the same current density. Remarkably, the corresponding overpotential values of these catalysts at the different current density are clearly shown in Fig. 3b. Among them, at high current density of 300 mA cm−2, FeCo-LDH still maintains an overpotential of only 278 mV, much smaller than Fe-LDH (318 mV), Co-LDH (439 mV), and bare NF (622 mV). This indicates that FeCo-LDH has great potential in practical industrial applications with high current density. The high overpotential of bare NF can prove from the side that although FeCo-LDH grows on NF in situ, the contribution of NF to its OER activity is small. Fig. S6 shows that LSV curves of FeCo-LDH directly grown in situ on NF and coated on NF as OER catalyst, at same current density, FeCo-LDH directly grown in situ on NF has obvious lower potential, which illustrates that the in situ grown materials can not only reduce the use of binders, but also improve the tightness of contact with the catalytic substrate, thereby enhancing the OER activity of FeCo-LDH. The corresponding Tafel slopes for the OER are shown in Fig. 3c, in which FeCo-LDH demonstrates an OER Tafel slope of 58.6 mV dec−1, comparatively lower than that of Fe-LDH (83.9 mV dec−1), Co-LDH (94.6 mV dec−1), and bare NF (136.9 mV dec−1). The smaller Tafel slopes demonstrating that FeCo-LDH has better catalytic activity and faster OER kinetics. In addition, the Tafel slope of FeCo-LDH is between 40 and 60 mV dec−1, which illustrates that its rate-limiting step is the O-O bond formation, which is the most demanding step in OER process when metal oxides are used as electrocatalysts [39,40]. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to evaluate the interface charge transfer between catalyst and electrolyte during OER. The Nyquist plots (Fig. S7) show that the semicircle of FeCo-LDH is smaller than other catalysts, suggesting that the material has smaller charge-transfer resistance (Rct) and better conductivity [40] . The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was researched by testing corresponding electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl) which measured by CV with different scanning speeds in the non-Faraday potential region (Fig. S8). The Cdl value of FeCo-LDH (4.20 mF cm−2) is higher than Fe-LDH (1.76 mF cm−2), Co-LDH (1.49 mF cm−2), and bare NF (1.03 mF cm−2), indicating that FeCo-LDH has a higher density of OER active sites (Fig. 3d). In order to determine the observed currents stemmed from O2 evolution, FE is researched. As shown in Fig. S9a, the O2 generated on the surface of FeCo-LDH loaded on the inner glassy carbon electrode can be reduced on the outer Pt ring with ring potential of 0.4 V vs. RHE. When the disk potential is 1.613 V vs. RHE, the disk and ring current density are 7.03 and 1.01 mA cm−2, respectively, the FE value is calculated to be 96.9% according to Eq. (1) (Fig. S9b). The FE value further demonstrates that the observed currents originate from the OER process [33] . The cyclic voltammetry (CV) in OER process with full range (−0.6 ~ 1.6 V vs. RHE) were shown in Fig. S10. To research the durability and sensitivity to potential response, multiple-current step test of FeCo-LDH in 1.0 M KOH for 30 min with current densities increasing from 50 to 200 mA cm−2 was performed (Fig. S11). At each current density, the voltages remain almost constant for 30 min, indicating that FeCo-LDH had a good durability. In the meantime, when switching the next step, the voltage responds in time with the change of time, and the response time is very short, almost unobservable, indicating that the sensitivity to potential response is super high (inset in Fig. S11). To further explore the durability of FeCo-LDH, the long-term chronopotentiometry (CP) stability is tested at current densities of 50 and 100 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. It can be observed that at these two current densities, the voltages are basically stable for 24 h (Fig. 3 e). The FeCo-LDH after 24 h CP test at current densities of 50 mA cm−2 is characterized by SEM (Fig. 3f), and it could be observed that the morphology and structure of LDH remained basically unchanged, only the edge was slightly etched in the OER process. All these indicate that FeCo-LDH has good durability in the OER process, which may benefit from the stability of morphology and structure. Different from the reaction mechanism of OER, UOR is an electrochemical oxidation process with 6-electron transfer, resulting in a very large overpotential in the complex UOR process [41] . However, its lower theoretical voltage (0.37 V vs. RHE) makes UOR worth studying. The results of FeCo-LDH and other samples as UOR catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. The UOR electrocatalytic activity is verified in electrolyte containing urea, and the LSV curves of FeCo-LDH and other catalysts are recorded in Fig. 4a. As expected, FeCo-LDH exhibits excellent UOR catalytic activity, outperforming other samples and commercial RuO2 (˃75%) (Fig. S12). FeCo-LDH requires less voltage to achieve the same current density. For instance, the voltage of FeCo-LDH only needs 1.328 V vs. RHE to obtain a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which are lower than Fe-LDH (1.357 V vs. RHE), Co-LDH (1.36 V vs. RHE), bare NF (1.394 V vs. RHE) (Fig. 4b), and even smaller than most of reported LDH related catalysts for UOR (Table S1). At the current density of 50 mA cm−2, the voltage of FeCo-LDH is 1.353 V vs. RHE. In UOR, the corresponding Tafel slopes are smaller than that of each electrocatalysts in OER, which is related to the lower reaction resistance encountered during the UOR reaction, reflecting better catalytic reaction kinetics. Similar to Tafel slopes in OER, FeCo-LDH has the smallest slope in UOR with only 28.8 mV dec−1, followed by Fe-LDH (54.4 mV dec−1), Co-LDH (55.9 mV dec−1), and bare NF with the largest slope of 65.2 mV dec−1. The displayed fast kinetic results correspond to the UOR catalytic activity exhibited by LSV, indicating that the high activity exhibited by FeCo-LDH in UOR is related to its small resistance in the catalytic process. The Cdl which measured by CV with different scanning speeds in the non-Faraday potential region (Fig. S13) is used to study the ECSA of FeCo-LDH, which for UOR is shown in Fig. 4d, and the Cdl value of FeCo-LDH (4.55 mF cm−2) is much larger than that of Fe-LDH (1.92 mF cm−2), Co-LDH (2.13 mF cm−2), bare NF (1.19 mF cm−2), they are also larger than Cdl in the OER reaction. And the Nyquist plots (Fig. S14) reflect the charge transfer abilities of FeCo-LDH and other electrocatalysts during UOR process. Comparing the radius of Nyquist plots of these electrocatalysts, the FeCo-LDH has the smallest radius, which indicates that FeCo-LDH has the smallest Rct, the highest conductivity, and the faster electron transfer kinetics. To investigate the durability of FeCo-LDH, the CP stability tests were performed in electrolyte containing urea at current densities of 10 and 50 mA cm−2 for 24 h (Fig. 4e). It can be found that at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, the voltage remains basically unchanged, while at the current density of 50 mA cm−2, the voltage rises by nearly 0.5 V, the possible reason is that at a larger current density, the voltage is higher, and a large amount of urea undergoes an electro-oxidation reaction, which leads to a decrease in the concentration of urea, and the generated CO2 has a certain effect on the stability of FeCo-LDH [42] . In addition, SEM is used to characterize FeCo-LDH after CP stability tests at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for 24 h to study the effect of its morphology and structure on the UOR durability (Fig. 4f). The morphology is basically unchanged, FeCo-LDH maintains a similar interlaced crossed nanosheet structure as before unreacted, and there is no trace of erosion on the edge of the sheet. It shows that FeCo-LDH has good structural stability during the UOR process, thus ensuring its excellent durability. The FeCo-LDH exhibited excellent OER and UOR catalytic properties. In order to exclude the effect of active surface area on the catalytic activity and thus more fairly compare the OER and UOR catalytic activity, the Cdl-normalized LSV curves of FeCo-LDH (Fig. S15) show that the voltage required for the UOR process is significantly lower than that of the OER process. The material composition changes and the real active centers of FeCo-LDH during OER and UOR processes are curious, so we tried to investigate this by XPS and XRD characterization studies. The XPS spectra of FeCo-LDH before and after OER and UOR were showed in Figs. 5 and S16. In general, the XPS spectra of FeCo-LDH after OER and UOR are similar, their spectral shapes are not same as that of initial FeCo-LDH, and the whole shifts to the direction of low binding energy, which possibly related to the changes in oxidation degree on the FeCo-LDH surface [43] . As Fig. 5 a showed, the peaks of Fe 2p after OER and UOR are shifted to small binding energy by ~0.6 eV and ~0.1 eV, respectively. The peaks of Co 2p (Fig. 5b) are moved to small binding energy by ~0.6 eV and ~0.5 eV after OER and UOR, respectively. In the meantime, the relative area of the split peaks of Co3+ is larger than that initial FeCo-LDH, indicating that their contents have been greatly improved, which is beneficial to the charge transport on the electrode/electrolyte interface, thereby ensuring good OER/UOR performance. In Fig. 5c, compared with initial XPS spectra of O 1 s, the split peaks of O1 at ~290.3 eV corresponding to oxygen bonding to metals are significantly enhanced, that which further indicated that metal oxyhydroxides like FeCoOOH are formed during OER and UOR [44] . The XRD patterns of FeCo-LDH on NF before reaction, after OER and UOR are exhibited in Fig. S16, the peaks of NF are almost unchanged, but the diffraction peaks of FeCo-LDH (PDF card no. 50–0235) become less obvious, indicating that the crystallinity of FeCo-LDH becomes lower during OER/UOR process, which can echo the test results of XPS, which proves that amorphous FeCoOOH with higher catalytic activity are formed on the surface of FeCo-LDH. Thus, FeCo-LDH acts as an electrocatalyst, and the FeCoOOH with higher catalytic activity are formed on the surface during OER/UOR process, which are called the electrocatalytically active phases [45] . The real catalytic active centers of FeCo-LDH during OER/UOR may be amorphous FeCoOOH. The FeCo-LDH as OER and UOR electrocatalyst has excellent performance, which motivated us to explore energy-efficient H2 production systems by using FeCo-LDH as an anodic catalyst and OER or UOR as an anodic reaction for water splitting. Therefore, FeCo-LDH was used as the anode and Pt/C as the cathode were assembled into a two-electrode system for water splitting in 1 M KOH with or without 0.5 M urea. When the OER as the anodic reaction and HER as the cathodic reaction in 1 M KOH, respectively, the water electrolysis process can be expressed by Eqs. (2)–(4) [14,46]. (2) Anode : 4 OH − → 2 H 2 O + 4 e − + O 2 (3) Cathode : 4 H 2 O + 4 e − → 2 H 2 + 4 O H − (4) Overall : 2 H 2 O → 2 H 2 + O 2 Among them, the theoretical open circuit voltage of water electrolysis is 1.23 V vs. RHE. When the UOR as the anode reaction and HER as the cathode reaction in electrolyte containing urea, respectively, the urea electrolysis process can be expressed by Eqs. (5)–(8) [41,47]. (5) Anode : CO ( NH 2 ) 2 + 6 OH − → N 2 + 5 H 2 O + CO 2 + 6 e − (6) C O 2 + 2 OH − → CO 3 2 − + H 2 O (7) Cathode : 6 H 2 O + 6 e − → 3 H 2 + 6 O H − (8) Overall : CO ( NH 2 ) 2 + 2 OH − → 3 H 2 + N 2 + CO 3 2 − Among them, the theoretical open circuit voltage of urea electrolysis is 0.37 V vs. RHE. The Fig. 6a shows that the LSV curves of FeCo-LDH as anodic electrocatalyst of coupled (+)OER‖HER(-) (water electrolysis) and (+)UOR‖HER(-) (urea electrolysis) at scanning rate of 2 mV s− 1, which clearly reveals great reaction kinetics of water electrolysis and urea electrolysis. Urea electrolysis needs cell voltages of 1.409 and 1.622 V to deliver current densities of 10 and 50 mA cm−2, respectively. The cell voltages are 114 and 90 mV smaller than water electrolysis, respectively. As a comparison, the LSV curves of FeCo-LDH, Fe-LDH, and Co-LDH, and RuO2 as anode and Pt/C as cathode for urea electrolysis (Fig. 6b) and water electrolysis (Fig. 6c) are exhibited. Compared with other anodic electrocatalysts, FeCo-LDH requires less cell voltage to achieve the same current density, which may be related to the larger active surface area of FeCo-LDH (derived from Cdl values in OER/UOR tests), more kinds of active sites, and the possible synergistic effect between Fe, Co, and NF. Accordingly, the voltage values required for these anodic catalysts to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 are given in Fig. 6d, which can be clearly observed that the voltage required for water splitting assisted by urea is less than that for direct water splitting, and the catalytic performance of catalysts with both Fe and Co is better than that of catalysts with only Fe or Co, and better than that of RuO2 as anode catalyst. Moreover, the (+)FeCo-LDH‖Pt/C(-) water splitting devices composed of water electrolysis and urea electrolysis methods show great stability by 24 h CP test at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH with or without 0.5 M urea (Fig. 6e). After the test system is stable, water splitting devices maintained a voltage of 1.539 V and 1.459 V in the stability test of water and urea electrolysis, respectively. After the stability test of urea electrolysis, catalytic ability and structure morphology of FeCo-LDH are investigated. The LSV curves before and after stability test (Fig. S17) almost coincide, indicating that FeCo-LDH does not change too much, thus demonstrating its excellent durability. And SEM image after stability test (Fig. S18) also showed very similar morphology to the previous one, without edge wear. Due to the excellent performance of urea-assisted water splitting for H2 production of FeCo-LDH, the 1.5 V commercial battery is used to drive the two-electrode device to observe whether effective water splitting to produce H2 can be achieved in electrolyte containing urea. It does not disappoint, as shown in Fig. 6f, when FeCo-LDH grown in situ on NF as the anode for UOR and Pt/C coated on NF as the cathode for HER to form a two-electrode device, it can be seen that a large number of H2 bubbles are generated on the cathode. Based on the above performance demonstrations, FeCo-LDH as anodic electrocatalyst does have better catalytic activity for water splitting. In conclusion, FeCo-LDH grown in situ on NF exhibits excellent OER and UOR catalytic ability and durability, which has good application in water splitting to produce H2. FeCo-LDH has such a good anode catalytic performance, mainly due to the following reasons: (1) The crossed nanosheet structure keeps FeCo-LDH structure and performance stable during catalysis; (2) There may be synergistic effect between Fe, Co, and NF, so that FeCo-LDH has more catalytic active centers than FeCo-LDH present in a single metal; (3) FeCo-LDH growing on NF that is directly used as catalyst has better mechanical adhesion and conductivity, meantime, without the use of binder, so that the active site is better exposed to the catalytic system, which is more conducive to mass transfer of reactants and rapid electron transfer. These characteristics are beneficial to the improvement of the catalytic ability of FeCo-LDH as OER and UOR catalysts. 4 Conclusions In summary, FeCo-LDH with crossed nanosheet structure as OER and UOR catalysts for water splitting to produce H2 was constructed by one-step hydrothermal method. FeCo-LDH exhibits excellent durability in the catalysis of OER, UOR and assisted water splitting process. The overpotential of OER is only 228 mV, and the voltage of UOR is only 1.353 V vs. RHE at a current density of 50 mA cm−2. In the water splitting process for H2 production, the voltages require to water and urea electrolysis with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 are 1.523 V and 1.409 V, respectively. From this it can be predicted that FeCo-LDH as anodic electrocatalyst for water splitting to produce H2 has tremendous application foreground. coredata.dc:description: To improve efficiency of hydrogen production, other anodic reactions with lower theoretical potential like urea oxidation reaction (UOR) to replace OER were explored. Herein, we synthesized FeCo layered double hydroxide (FeCo-LDH) in situ on nickel foam (NF) that had excellent OER and UOR catalytic ability and durability. The good catalytic performance can be attributed to the special crossed nanosheet structured FeCo-LDH with large specific surface area, rapid electron transfer. At the current density of 50 mA cm−2, the overpotential is 228 mV during OER, and the voltage value is 1.353 V vs. RHE during UOR. When FeCo-LDH was used as electrocatalyst, the voltages required for water and urea electrolysis to reach the current density of 10 mA cm−2 are 1.523 V and 1.409 V, respectively. The strategy of constructing FeCo-LDH on NF plays an important role in high efficiency hydrogen production, and has great application prospects in sustainable energy efficient conversion.
coredata.dc:title: High efficiency UOR electrocatalyst based on crossed nanosheet structured FeCo-LDH for hydrogen production
